greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: 10-adic integer x=.....06619977392256259918212890624 satisfying x^3 = x.
comment: Let a,b be integers defined in A018247, A018248 satisfying a^2=a, b^2=b, obviously a^3=a, b^3=b; let c,d,e,f be integers defined in A091661, A063006, A091663, A091664 then c^3=c, d^3=d, e^3=e, f^3=f, c+d=1, a+e=1, b+f=1, b+c=a, d+f=e, a+f=c, a=f+1, b=e+1, cd=-1, af=-1, gh=-1 where -1=.....999999999.
link: Seiichi Manyama, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..9999 (terms 0..999 from Paul D. Hanna)
formula: For n > 0, a(n) = 9 - A018248(n) = A018247(n). - _Seiichi Manyama_, Jul 28 2017
example: x equals the limit of the (n+1) trailing digits of 4^(5^n):
mathematica: To calculate c, d, e, f use Mathematica algorithms for a, b and equations: c=a-b, d=1-c, e=b-1, f=a-1.
program: (PARI) {a(n)=local(b=4,v=[]); for(k=1, n+1, b=b^5%10^k; v=concat(v,(10*b\10^k))); v[n+1]} \\ _Paul D. Hanna_, Jul 06 2006
results.author: Edoardo Gueglio (egueglio(AT)yahoo.it), Jan 28 2004
